q: What are the symptoms of hypersomnia?
a: Common symptoms of hypersomnia include regularly napping during the day, falling asleep during the day, and sleeping for long hours at night.

q: When should I see a GP if I experience excessive sleepiness?
a: You should see a GP if you often fall asleep during the day and if sleepiness is affecting your life.

q: What happens at a GP appointment for excessive sleepiness?
a: During your appointment, the GP may ask about possible causes of your sleepiness, suggest keeping a sleep diary, or refer you to a specialist in sleep disorders. Treatment will depend on the underlying cause.

q: What are some possible causes of hypersomnia?
a: Possible causes of hypersomnia include conditions like narcolepsy, sleep apnea, restless legs syndrome, depression, bipolar disorder, and myalgic encephalomyelitis (ME/CFS). Certain medications, alcohol, and drug use can also contribute.

q: What are some things I can try to improve my sleeping habits?
a: You can try going to bed at the same time every night, avoiding alcohol and caffeine, creating a peaceful sleeping environment, avoiding medications that cause drowsiness, and refraining from working late into the night. It may also help to talk to your family and friends about your excessive sleepiness.

q: What should I do if I'm diagnosed with hypersomnia and want to drive?
a: If you're diagnosed with hypersomnia, you'll need to inform the Driver and Vehicle Licensing Agency (DVLA) and you may not be able to drive. Learn more about the rules on excessive sleepiness and driving from GOV.UK.

q: What is idiopathic hypersomnia?
a: Idiopathic hypersomnia is a type of hypersomnia where someone sleeps for long periods and wakes up feeling confused or irritable (known as sleep inertia) and not refreshed. The cause of idiopathic hypersomnia is unknown.
